Theoretical Background

Source: vignettes/theoretical-background.Rmd
theoretical-background.Rmd

Overview

This vignette provides the theoretical foundation for the CorOncoEndpoints package, covering:

  • The Fleischer model for OS and PFS
  • Copula-based modeling of dependence
  • Correlation bounds (Fr√©chet-Hoeffding)
  • Mathematical derivations

The Fleischer Model

Model Specification

The Fleischer model (2009) provides a framework for modeling the dependence between overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS).

Key Components:

  1. Overall Survival (OS): OS‚àºExp(ŒªOS)OS \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda_{OS})
  2. Time to Progression (TTP): TTP‚àºExp(ŒªTTP)TTP \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda_{TTP})
  3. Progression-Free Survival (PFS): PFS=min(OS,TTP)PFS = \min(OS, TTP)

where OS and TTP are independent.

Important Properties

Property 1: PFS follows an exponential distribution PFS‚àºExp(ŒªPFS)PFS \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda_{PFS}) where ŒªPFS=ŒªOS+ŒªTTP\lambda_{PFS} = \lambda_{OS} + \lambda_{TTP}

Proof: Since PFS=min(OS,TTP)PFS = \min(OS, TTP) with independent exponentials, P(PFS>t)=P(OS>t)‚ãÖP(TTP>t)=e‚àíŒªOSt‚ãÖe‚àíŒªTTPt=e‚àí(ŒªOS+ŒªTTP)tP(PFS > t) = P(OS > t) \cdot P(TTP > t) = e^{-\lambda_{OS}t} \cdot e^{-\lambda_{TTP}t} = e^{-(\lambda_{OS} + \lambda_{TTP})t}

Property 2: Correlation between OS and PFS Corr(OS,PFS)=ŒªOSŒªPFS=ŒªOSŒªOS+ŒªTTP\text{Corr}(OS, PFS) = \frac{\lambda_{OS}}{\lambda_{PFS}} = \frac{\lambda_{OS}}{\lambda_{OS} + \lambda_{TTP}}

This ensures 0<Corr(OS,PFS)<10 < \text{Corr}(OS, PFS) < 1 and automatically satisfies PFS‚â§OSPFS \leq OS.

Median Survival Times

For exponentially distributed time-to-event variables: Median=log(2)Œª\text{Median} = \frac{\log(2)}{\lambda}

Therefore: - Median OS = log(2)ŒªOS\frac{\log(2)}{\lambda_{OS}} - Median PFS = log(2)ŒªPFS\frac{\log(2)}{\lambda_{PFS}}

Copula-Based Dependence Modeling

What is a Copula?

A copula is a function that links marginal distributions to their joint distribution. For two random variables XX and YY with marginal distributions FXF_X and FYF_Y, the copula CC satisfies:

FX,Y(x,y)=C(FX(x),FY(y))F_{X,Y}(x,y) = C(F_X(x), F_Y(y))

Why Copulas?

Copulas allow us to:

  1. Separate marginal behavior from dependence structure
  2. Model non-linear dependencies
  3. Handle different types of tail dependence

Clayton Copula

Definition: C(u,v;Œ∏)=(u‚àíŒ∏+v‚àíŒ∏‚àí1)‚àí1/Œ∏,Œ∏>0C(u, v; \theta) = (u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1)^{-1/\theta}, \quad \theta > 0

Properties:

  • Lower tail dependence: ŒªL=2‚àí1/Œ∏\lambda_L = 2^{-1/\theta}
  • Upper tail independence: ŒªU=0\lambda_U = 0
  • Kendall‚Äôs tau: œÑ=Œ∏/(Œ∏+2)\tau = \theta / (\theta + 2)
  • Cannot model negative dependence (requires Œ∏>0\theta > 0)

Conditional Distribution: C2|1(v|u;Œ∏)=‚àÇC(u,v;Œ∏)‚àÇu=u‚àíŒ∏‚àí1(u‚àíŒ∏+v‚àíŒ∏‚àí1)‚àí1/Œ∏‚àí1C_{2|1}(v|u; \theta) = \frac{\partial C(u,v;\theta)}{\partial u} = u^{-\theta-1}(u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1)^{-1/\theta - 1}

This is used in the generation algorithm.

Frank Copula

Definition: C(u,v;Œ∏)=‚àí1Œ∏log(1+(e‚àíŒ∏u‚àí1)(e‚àíŒ∏v‚àí1)e‚àíŒ∏‚àí1)C(u, v; \theta) = -\frac{1}{\theta} \log\left(1 + \frac{(e^{-\theta u} - 1)(e^{-\theta v} - 1)}{e^{-\theta} - 1}\right)

Properties:

  • Symmetric: No tail dependence (ŒªL=ŒªU=0\lambda_L = \lambda_U = 0)
  • Kendall‚Äôs tau: œÑ=1‚àí4Œ∏[1‚àíD1(Œ∏)]\tau = 1 - \frac{4}{\theta}\left[1 - D_1(\theta)\right] where D1D_1 is the Debye function
  • Can model negative dependence (Œ∏\theta can be negative)

Conditional Distribution: C2|1(v|u;Œ∏)=(e‚àíŒ∏v‚àí1)(e‚àíŒ∏‚àí1)(e‚àíŒ∏v‚àí1)+(e‚àíŒ∏u‚àí1)(e‚àíŒ∏‚àí1)C_{2|1}(v|u; \theta) = \frac{(e^{-\theta v} - 1)(e^{-\theta} - 1)}{(e^{-\theta v} - 1) + (e^{-\theta u} - 1)(e^{-\theta} - 1)}

Correlation Bounds

Fr√©chet-Hoeffding Bounds

For any copula CC: max(u+v‚àí1,0)‚â§C(u,v)‚â§min(u,v)\max(u + v - 1, 0) \leq C(u,v) \leq \min(u, v)

These bounds correspond to:

  • Lower bound: Perfect negative dependence (countermonotonic copula)
  • Upper bound: Perfect positive dependence (comonotonic copula)

Correlation Bounds for TTE and Binary Response

For a time-to-event variable T‚àºExp(Œª)T \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda) and binary response R‚àºBernoulli(p)R \sim \text{Bernoulli}(p):

Lower Bound: œÅlower=‚àíp1‚àíp‚à´0qpe‚àíŒªtdt\rho_{lower} = -\sqrt{\frac{p}{1-p}} \int_0^{q_p} e^{-\lambda t} dt

where qpq_p is the pp-th quantile of the exponential distribution.

Upper Bound: œÅupper=1‚àípp‚à´qp‚àûe‚àíŒªtdt\rho_{upper} = \sqrt{\frac{1-p}{p}} \int_{q_p}^\infty e^{-\lambda t} dt

These simplify to: œÅlower=‚àíp1‚àíp(1‚àíp)\rho_{lower} = -\sqrt{\frac{p}{1-p}}(1 - p)œÅupper=1‚àípp‚ãÖp\rho_{upper} = \sqrt{\frac{1-p}{p}} \cdot p

Important: These bounds depend only on pp, not on Œª\lambda (for the TTE-Response case).

Correlation Bounds for PFS and Response

In the three-endpoint framework (OS + PFS + Response), the bounds for PFS-Response correlation are more complex and depend on both pp and the hazard rates:

œÅlowerPFS=1‚àíppŒªOSŒªTTP[(1‚àíp)ŒªTTP/ŒªOS‚àí1]\rho_{lower}^{PFS} = \sqrt{\frac{1-p}{p}} \frac{\lambda_{OS}}{\lambda_{TTP}} \left[(1-p)^{\lambda_{TTP}/\lambda_{OS}} - 1\right]

œÅupperPFS=p1‚àípŒªOSŒªTTP[1‚àípŒªTTP/ŒªOS]\rho_{upper}^{PFS} = \sqrt{\frac{p}{1-p}} \frac{\lambda_{OS}}{\lambda_{TTP}} \left[1 - p^{\lambda_{TTP}/\lambda_{OS}}\right]

where ŒªTTP=ŒªPFS‚àíŒªOS\lambda_{TTP} = \lambda_{PFS} - \lambda_{OS}.

Data Generation Algorithm

Step 1: Generate Uniform Random Variables

For copula-based generation:

  1. Generate U1‚àºUniform(0,1)U_1 \sim \text{Uniform}(0,1)
  2. Generate U2‚àºUniform(0,1)U_2 \sim \text{Uniform}(0,1)

Step 2: Apply Copula Transform

Use the conditional copula to transform U2U_2: V=C2|1(U2|U1;Œ∏)V = C_{2|1}(U_2|U_1; \theta)

Now (U1,V)(U_1, V) have the desired dependence structure.

Step 3: Apply Inverse CDF Transform

Transform uniforms to target distributions:

  • For TTE: T=‚àí1Œªlog(1‚àíU1)T = -\frac{1}{\lambda}\log(1 - U_1)
  • For Response: R=ùüô{V>1‚àíp}R = \mathbb{1}\{V > 1 - p\}

where ùüô{‚ãÖ}\mathbb{1}\{\cdot\} is the indicator function.

Step 4: Enforce PFS ‚â§ OS Constraint

When generating all three endpoints:

  1. Generate OS‚àºExp(ŒªOS)OS \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda_{OS})
  2. Generate TTP‚àºExp(ŒªTTP)TTP \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda_{TTP}) independently
  3. Set PFS=min(OS,TTP)PFS = \min(OS, TTP)

This automatically ensures PFS‚â§OSPFS \leq OS.

Calculating Copula Parameters

From Correlation to Theta

Given desired correlation œÅ\rho between TTE and Response, we need to find copula parameter Œ∏\theta.

For Clayton Copula:

Solve numerically: œÅ=Corr(T,R)=fClayton(Œ∏,p,Œª)\rho = \text{Corr}(T, R) = f_{Clayton}(\theta, p, \lambda)

using Hoeffding‚Äôs formula for covariance.

For Frank Copula:

Solve numerically: œÅ=Corr(T,R)=fFrank(Œ∏,p,Œª)\rho = \text{Corr}(T, R) = f_{Frank}(\theta, p, \lambda)

The package implements these using numerical optimization (bisection method).

Validation Metrics

Bias

Bias(Œ∏ÃÇ)=E[Œ∏ÃÇ]‚àíŒ∏\text{Bias}(\hat{\theta}) = E[\hat{\theta}] - \theta

Measures systematic error. Should be close to 0 for unbiased estimators.

Mean Squared Error (MSE)

MSE(Œ∏ÃÇ)=E[(Œ∏ÃÇ‚àíŒ∏)2]=Var(Œ∏ÃÇ)+Bias2(Œ∏ÃÇ)\text{MSE}(\hat{\theta}) = E[(\hat{\theta} - \theta)^2] = \text{Var}(\hat{\theta}) + \text{Bias}^2(\hat{\theta})

Combines variance and bias into a single measure.

Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE)

RMSE(Œ∏ÃÇ)=MSE(Œ∏ÃÇ)\text{RMSE}(\hat{\theta}) = \sqrt{\text{MSE}(\hat{\theta})}

Error measure in the original scale.

Relative Bias

Relative Bias(Œ∏ÃÇ)=Bias(Œ∏ÃÇ)Œ∏√ó100%\text{Relative Bias}(\hat{\theta}) = \frac{\text{Bias}(\hat{\theta})}{\theta} \times 100\%

Expresses bias as a percentage of the true value.

Mathematical Derivations

Derivation of Corr(OS, PFS)

Given PFS=min(OS,TTP)PFS = \min(OS, TTP) with OS‚àºExp(Œª1)OS \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda_1) and TTP‚àºExp(Œª2)TTP \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda_2) independent:

E[PFS‚ãÖOS]=E[PFS]‚ãÖE[OS|PFS=OS]‚ãÖP(PFS=OS)+E[PFS]‚ãÖE[OS|PFS<OS]‚ãÖP(PFS<OS)E[PFS \cdot OS] = E[PFS] \cdot E[OS|PFS = OS] \cdot P(PFS = OS) + E[PFS] \cdot E[OS|PFS < OS] \cdot P(PFS < OS)

After integration: Cov(OS,PFS)=1(Œª1+Œª2)2\text{Cov}(OS, PFS) = \frac{1}{(\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)^2}

And since: Var(OS)=1Œª12,Var(PFS)=1(Œª1+Œª2)2\text{Var}(OS) = \frac{1}{\lambda_1^2}, \quad \text{Var}(PFS) = \frac{1}{(\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)^2}

We get: Corr(OS,PFS)=Cov(OS,PFS)Var(OS)‚ãÖVar(PFS)=Œª1Œª1+Œª2\text{Corr}(OS, PFS) = \frac{\text{Cov}(OS, PFS)}{\sqrt{\text{Var}(OS) \cdot \text{Var}(PFS)}} = \frac{\lambda_1}{\lambda_1 + \lambda_2}

Derivation of PFS-Response Correlation

In the three-endpoint framework, the correlation between PFS and Response is derived from:

  1. The specified correlation between OS and Response
  2. The Fleischer model relationship PFS=min(OS,TTP)PFS = \min(OS, TTP)
  3. The copula linking OS and Response

The derivation involves: Cov(PFS,R)=E[PFS‚ãÖR]‚àíE[PFS]‚ãÖE[R]\text{Cov}(PFS, R) = E[PFS \cdot R] - E[PFS] \cdot E[R]

This requires computing integrals over the copula-linked distributions, which is done numerically in the package.

References

  1. Fleischer, F., Gaschler-Markefski, B., & Bluhmki, E. (2009). A statistical model for the dependence between progression-free survival and overall survival. Statistics in Medicine, 28(21), 2669-2686.

  2. Trivedi, P. K., & Zimmer, D. M. (2005). Copula modeling: an introduction for practitioners. Foundations and Trends in Econometrics, 1(1), 1-111.

  3. Nelsen, R. B. (2006). An introduction to copulas (2nd ed.). Springer.

  4. Hofert, M., Kojadinovic, I., Maechler, M., & Yan, J. (2018). Elements of copula modeling with R. Springer.

  5. Joe, H. (2014). Dependence modeling with copulas. CRC Press.

Summary

This vignette provided the mathematical foundation for:

  • The Fleischer model for OS and PFS
  • Copula-based dependence modeling (Clayton and Frank)
  • Correlation bounds based on Fr√©chet-Hoeffding bounds
  • Data generation algorithms
  • Validation metrics

Understanding these concepts helps users: - Choose appropriate parameter values - Interpret simulation results - Validate model assumptions - Extend the methodology
